awd_titl_txt: Workshop on Natural Language Processing for Internet Freedom
awd_abstract_narration:
This workshop brings together natural language processing (NLP) researchers whose work contributes to the free flow of information on the Internet. It should foster collaboration across disciplines, and between theoreticians and practitioners working in academic or industrial settings. This workshop could have a transformative impact on society by getting closer to achieving Internet freedom in countries where accessing and sharing of information are strictly controlled by censorship.

The topics of interest in this workshop include censorship detection, censorship circumvention
techniques, linguistically inspired countermeasures for Internet censorship, and techniques to
empirically measure Internet censorship across communication platforms. The workshop includes researchers working in the field of NLP, computer science and social sciences. Graduate students, faculty, and researchers from industry will participate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
A series of workshops named NLP for Internet Freedom (NLP4IF) were organized to address challenges associated with online censorship, disinformation, and propaganda. These workshops brought together experts from various fields -- incuding natural language processing (NLP), political science, journalism, and civil society organizations --  leading to the development of innovative techniques to tackle these challenges.


Multiple shared tasks, also known as contests, were organized to encourage the creation of tools to spot propaganda and online censorship (e.g., see https://gitlab.com/NLP4IF and https://propaganda.qcri.org/nlp4if-shared-task/). These tasks attracted a diverse group of participants who introduced novel methodologies to counter the dissemination of false information. The datasets, systems, and publications detailing these approaches are publicly available online: https://aclanthology.org/venues/nlp4if/


The workshops also extended their focus to ethical considerations within the field of NLP, raising awareness about privacy concerns.


Furthermore, the COVID-19 pandemic has significantly impacted people worldwide. Regrettably, there have been deliberate attempts to spread false information to undermine the public health responses and to push alternative agendas. Our workshop addressed these issues as well through organized panels, shared tasks, and workshop presentations (http://www.netcopia.net/nlp4if/).


In conclusion, NLP4IF demonstrated the potential of NLP in promoting a more transparent and inclusive digital environment, contributing to global initiatives in support of Internet freedom.

 


Last Modified: 08/14/2023
Modified by: Anna Feldman
